titleInfo.title: Advancing Methods for Improving the Robustness of Evidence Syntheses

mods:mods.abstract: Evidence synthesis has been widely used in contemporary evidence-based medicine. In evidence synthesis, systematic reviews and meta-analyses are transparent and reproducible methods for synthesizing data from multiple sources, thereby informing healthcare and clinical decision-making with high-quality synthesized evidence. However, the heterogeneity between studies and the potential for publication bias can compromise the validity of synthesized results, leading to unreliable or biased conclusions. This dissertation introduces novel statistical methods to assess these two critical issues in pairwise meta-analyses. It proposes tipping point analyses to evaluate the impact of heterogeneity parameters on the robustness of meta-analytical findings. Furthermore, the dissertation refines the current popular trim-and-fill method to improve its performance in adjusting for publication bias. First, we introduce an arm-based meta-analysis model, bivariate generalized linear mixed effects model, which models the distribution of absolute treatment effects. The arm-based model has several advantages, including providing flexible outcome measures and the ability to incorporate single-arm studies and double-zero event studies without further adjustments, which improves estimation efficiency. However, its inference heavily depends on the heterogeneity parameters (i.e., between-arm correlation and heterogeneity standard deviations) related to design and model assumptions. To address this, we develop tipping point analyses within a Bayesian framework to assess the robustness of meta-analysis results. We initially evaluate the tipping point analysis for the between-arm correlation, and subsequently assess the tipping point analysis for the heterogeneity standard deviations. Finally, we discuss the trim-and-fill method, a popular approach for detecting and adjusting for publication bias by imputing missing studies. However, the original trim-and-fill method has limitations because it relies on a single point estimate for the number of missing studies and overlooks the corresponding estimation errors. We refine this method by incorporating the distribution of the number of missing studies into the analysis. The original and refined trim-and-fill methods are compared in various scenarios, including with and without heterogeneity among studies. By integrating the uncertainty of missing studies estimates and data resamplings, researchers can produce more reliable and robust interval estimates of the adjusted overall effect size, thereby enhancing the validity of meta-analysis findings.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Statistics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Arm-based model, Meta-analysis, Publication bias, Tipping point analysis

Lifeng Lin, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Xufeng Niu, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Zhe He, University Representative; Andrés Felipe Barrientos, Committee Member; Rongjie Liu, Committee Member.
